content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays several pieces of tissue, likely lymph nodes, based on their ovoid shape and dense, basophilic (purple) staining. I can identify at least four distinct tissue fragments of varying sizes. The overall appearance suggests a lymph node dissection for cancer staging.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my goal is to examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The highlighted area is one of the smaller, distinct tissue fragments in the lower-left portion of the slide. It is crucial to examine every piece of tissue, regardless of size, as even small nodes can harbor metastatic tumor cells. I am zooming in to assess the cellular architecture and cytology of this specific lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located on the periphery of the largest lymph node on the left. The border of the node in this specific region appears irregular and interfaces directly with the surrounding paler, fatty tissue. This interface between the lymph node capsule and the perinodal fat is a critical location to examine for metastasis. I am specifically looking for evidence of tumor cells breaching the capsule and invading the surrounding adipose tissue, a finding known as extranodal extension (ENE), which has significant prognostic implications. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the largest lymph node on the left. This area is crucial because the subcapsular sinus, located just beneath the outer capsule, is the most common initial site for metastatic tumor cells to deposit after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. Examining this specific region is a high-yield part of the search for early metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is one of the candidate lymph nodes that needs to be assessed for metastatic disease. This appears to be the third, and smallest, distinct lymph node on the slide (counting from the top). It is standard practice to systematically examine every lymph node at high magnification to rule out the presence of tumor cells, which is critical for cancer staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area to systematically examine each lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The selected area is the third lymph node from the top. The specific region of interest is the periphery of the lymph node, including the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. This is a critical area because metastatic tumor cells often first arrive and deposit in the subcapsular sinus, making it a high-yield location to screen for early metastatic disease. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area reveals a dense, diffuse population of small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells that would be characteristic of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a lymph node that is negative for metastatic carcinoma. The architecture is that of a lymph node, albeit without prominent follicular structures in this particular field.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the area of interest is the interface between the lymph node and the perinodal fat. On the left, there is a dense sheet of dark purple cells, characteristic of lymphoid tissue. On the right, there is mature adipose tissue (fat). The most striking feature is that the lymphoid cells are not contained within a smooth capsule but are seen irregularly infiltrating the adjacent fat. This architectural feature represents extranodal extension. While definitive malignant epithelial cells (e.g., forming glands) are not clearly identifiable in this specific field, the presence of extranodal extension is a strong indicator that the node is positive for metastasis. The pathologist would now carefully scrutinize the infiltrating cells at higher magnification to confirm they are carcinoma and not just reactive lymphocytes. The dark, sharp lines are cutting artifacts.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this magnified view, I see the edge of the lymph node, including the fibrous capsule at the top, adjacent adipose (fat) tissue, and the subcapsular sinus. The parenchyma of the node is densely populated with a monotonous population of small, dark lymphocytes. I am carefully inspecting the subcapsular sinus for any atypical cells, such as clusters of epithelial cells or glandular formations, which would indicate metastasis. In this particular field, I do not see any definitive malignant cells; the cells in the sinus appear to be benign histiocytes and lymphocytes. My impression of this specific area is that it is likely a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. However, I would need to continue scanning the entire circumference and substance of the node to make a final diagnosis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area reveals a cross-section of a lymph node surrounded by adipose tissue. The nodal architecture is preserved, showing a dense population of lymphocytes, which appear to be organized into follicles. I do not see any definite clusters of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal gland formation, or other features suggestive of metastatic carcinoma. My initial impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. I would still pan across the entire node to confirm this finding before moving on to the next one.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I can see the edge of the lymph node, characterized by dense lymphoid tissue (bottom left). Adjacent to this is the fibrous lymph node capsule and surrounding pericapsular connective tissue and fat. Within the subcapsular sinus and potentially infiltrating the capsule, there are distinct clusters of atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and form irregular glandular structures. The nuclei are enlarged, pleomorphic, and hyperchromatic. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this lymph node is positive for metastasis.
